subject: Art & Design
title: Designing for Color Blindness
description: A micro-lesson that makes Designing for Color Blindness usable.

hook.text: 8% of men are red-green color blind. If your error states are red-only, millions of users can't see them.

buildup.text: Color blindness means certain colors appear identical. Red/green confusion is most common.

discovery.text: Never use color as the only indicator. Add icons, patterns, labels, or borders alongside color signals.

twist.text: Tools like Sim Daltonism and Stark simulate color blindness. Test your designs â€” what you see isn't universal.

climax.text: Accessible color design isn't a niche concern. With 300 million color-blind people, it's mainstream.

punchline.text: Good design works for everyone's eyes, not just yours.

quiz.question: Why should color never be the only indicator of meaning?
